xiv LETTERS OF DANTE

The earliest independent testimony is that furnished by two of Dante’s contemporaries, namely the astrologor- poet Francescc degli Stabili, better known as Gecco d'Ascoli, who was burned as a free-thinker at Florence six years after Dante’s death ; and the chronicler Giovanni Villani, who was Dante’s neighbour in Florence‚ and, as his nephew Filippo records, was a personal friend of the poet (‘Patruus meus J ohannes Villani hystoricus . Danti fuit amicus et sotius ').¹ Gecco d’Ascoli in the third book of his encyclopaedic poem L’Acerba treats of the origin of nobility‚ which he says had already been treated of by the Florentino poet in his polished verse:

the reference, of course, being to the canzone ‘ Le dolci rime d' amor, ch’ io solia ³ prefixed to the fourth book of the Convivia Gecco controverts Dante's theory, and maintains that nobility is due *to the influence of one of the heavens, namely that of Mercury, upon the individual possessed of ancient blood ; ‘ but hei-eupon,’ he interjects, ‘Dante wrote to me to express a doubt, saying: “Two sons are born at a birth, and the elder turns out more

ond' io, ancora lagrimando in questa desolata cittade, scrissi a' principi della terra alquanto della sua condizione, pigliando quello cominciamento di Geremia profeta: Quomodo sedet sola civitas! . . . E se alcuno volesse me riprendere di cio, che non scrivo qui le parole ohe seguitano a quelle allegate, scusomene, perocche lo intendimento mio non fu da principio di scrivere altro che per volgare: onde, conciossiacosache 10 parole, che seguitano a quelle ohe sono allegate, sieno tutte latine, sarebbe fuori del mio intendi- mento se io le scrivessi ’ (ξ 31, 11. 1-21).
